selected.extractionSummary: This academic paper develops mathematical functions to analyze harmony in Just Intonation, where frequencies are rational number ratios. The author introduces the 'Complexity' measure (ratio of LCM to GCD) and other invariant functions to quantify consonance, arguing that Just Intonation provides the fundamental basis for understanding harmony that 12-tone equal temperament only approximates. The paper presents tools for systematically exploring harmonies beyond traditional Western music.

claims.text: Harmonies are more pleasing and consonant when frequency ratios use small whole numbers

citations.label: fundamental theorem
citations.quote: the harmonies which are more pleasing and consonant to the human ear are those where the frequency ratios are between small whole numbers

citations.label: historical consensus
citations.quote: as the ancient Greeks and Chinese discovered (using instruments like monochords) and as scientists through history have reiterated (Zarlino, Mersenne, Euler, Helmholtz)

claims.text: 12-tone equal temperament has no explanatory power for harmony and only works because it approximates Just Intonation

citations.label: author's thesis
citations.quote: 12-EDO has no explanatory power of harmony, it only works since it approximates a small part of JI well. The structure of JI is where the explanatory power resides.

citations.label: explanatory argument
citations.quote: 12-EDO cannot explain why a major triad should be supplied by notes (n, n+4, n+7) of the piano keyboard scale; why not (n, n+4, n+8)? The only satisfactory explanation is that the 12-EDO note pattern (n, n+4, n+7) approximates the JI frequency ratio 4:5:6 well.

claims.text: The Benedetti Height function (product of numerator and denominator in lowest terms) measures consonance complexity

citations.label: mathematical definition
citations.quote: BH is the ratio of minimum to maximum feature sizes of the combined waveform, and the Benedetti height could be described as a 'complexity' measure for adding these two sine waves

citations.label: consonance correlation
citations.quote: For BenedettiHeight a lower number means a more consonant interval, and a higher number means a more dissonant interval

claims.text: Ancient Greek consonant intervals were restricted to ratios between numbers 1, 2, 3, and 4

citations.label: historical limit
citations.quote: In ancient Greek times it appears that frequency (or string length) ratios regarded as consonant were restricted to ratios between the numbers 1, 2, 3 and 4. These numbers yielded the octave (2:1), perfect fifth (3:2) and perfect fourth (4:3).

claims.text: By Mersenne's time, the musical numbers had expanded to include 5 and 6, enabling major and minor thirds

citations.label: historical expansion
citations.quote: By the time of Mersenne the 'musical numbers' had expanded to be 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6. This gave a major third of 5:4 and a minor third of 6:5

claims.text: Otonal and utonal versions of chords sound different despite being mathematically dual

citations.label: perceptual observation
citations.quote: One interesting fact is that otonal and utonal versions of chords sound different to the human ear (e.g. major and minor sound different) although mathematically they are completely dual

selected.extractionSummary: Just intonation is a tuning system where frequency intervals are whole number ratios, creating 'pure' intervals based on the harmonic series. Unlike equal temperament, these systems are categorized by 'limits' - the highest prime factor used in the ratios. The most common Western version is 5-limit tuning, exemplified by Ptolemy's intense diatonic scale, which creates perfect major and minor triads but introduces complications like wolf intervals.

claims.text: Just intonation uses frequency intervals that are whole number ratios, making them 'pure' intervals from a single harmonic series

citations.label: definition
citations.quote: just intonation or pure intonation is a tuning system in which the space between notes' frequencies (called intervals) is a whole number ratio

citations.label: harmonic basis
citations.quote: Just intervals (and chords created by combining them) consist of tones from a single harmonic series of an implied fundamental

claims.text: In just intonation, if notes G3 and C4 are tuned as members of the harmonic series, their frequency ratio is 4:3

citations.label: example calculation
citations.quote: if the notes G 3 and C 4 (labelled 3 and 4) are tuned as members of the harmonic series of the lowest C, their frequencies will be 3 and 4 times the fundamental frequency. The interval ratio between C 4 and G 3 is therefore 4:3

claims.text: Bowed string instruments are typically tuned using pure fifths or fourths, while keyboards use equal temperament

citations.label: instrument practices
citations.quote: bowed instruments such as violins, violas, cellos, and double basses are tuned using pure fifths or fourths. In contrast, keyboard instruments are rarely tuned using only pure intervals

claims.text: The 5-limit just major third (5:4 ratio) deviates from 12-TET by −13.686 cents

citations.label: cent measurement
citations.quote: the major third is 400 cents in 12-TET, but the 5th harmonic, 5:4 is 386.314 cents. Thus, the just major third deviates by −13.686 cents

claims.text: Ptolemy described a 5-limit diatonic scale called 'intense diatonic' in his 2nd century text Harmonics

citations.label: historical reference
citations.quote: During the second century AD, Claudius Ptolemy described a 5-limit diatonic scale in his influential text on music theory Harmonics, which he called "intense diatonic"

claims.text: The Chinese guqin uses harmonic overtone positions marked by dots on its soundboard at specific fractional positions

citations.label: guqin positions
citations.quote: In China, the guqin has a musical scale based on harmonic overtone positions. The dots on its soundboard indicate the harmonic positions: ⁠1/8⁠, ⁠1/6⁠, ⁠1/5⁠, ⁠1/4⁠, ⁠1/3⁠, ⁠2/5⁠, ⁠1/2⁠, ⁠3/5⁠, ⁠2/3⁠, ⁠3/4⁠, ⁠4/5⁠, ⁠5/6⁠, ⁠7/8⁠

claims.text: In Ptolemy's intense diatonic scale, the interval from D to A creates a wolf fifth with ratio 40/27 (about 680 cents)

citations.label: wolf interval calculation
citations.quote: In this example the interval from D up to A would be a wolf fifth with the ratio ⁠ 40 / 27 ⁠, about 680 cents; noticeably smaller than the 702 cents of the pure ⁠ 3 / 2 ⁠ ratio

details.description: uses ratios including powers of 2 and 3

details.context: D to A in Ptolemy's scale

selected.sourceTitle: Pulsar Found Near the Center of the Milky Way Could Test Einstein’s Theories
selected.extractionSummary: Researchers discovered an 8.19-millisecond pulsar near Sagittarius A*, the supermassive black hole at the center of the Milky Way. Pulsars are rapidly rotating neutron stars that emit regular electromagnetic radiation pulses, acting as cosmic timekeepers. This discovery could enable precise tests of Einstein's general relativity by measuring how the black hole's gravity affects the pulsar's regular timing patterns.

claims.text: Pulsars emit bursts of electromagnetic radiation at regular intervals, making them function as precise cosmic timekeepers

citations.label: pulsar definition
citations.quote: Pulsars are highly magnetized, rapidly rotating neutron stars that emit bursts of electromagnetic radiation from their poles at regular intervals as they spin

citations.label: timekeeping function
citations.quote: Because pulsars blast out radiation at regular intervals, they can act as timekeepers of a sort

claims.text: Millisecond pulsars are especially regular in their timing compared to other pulsars

citations.label: millisecond pulsar precision
citations.quote: Millisecond pulsars, like the one located by the team, are especially regular

claims.text: Gravitational influences from massive objects can introduce measurable timing anomalies in pulsar signals

citations.label: gravitational timing effects
citations.quote: Any external influence on a pulsar, such as the gravitational pull of a massive object, would introduce anomalies in this steady arrival of pulses, which can be measured and modeled

claims.text: Electromagnetic pulses traveling near massive objects experience deflection and time delays due to spacetime warping

citations.label: relativistic effects on pulses
citations.quote: when the pulses travel near a very massive object, they may be deflected and experience time delays due to the warping of spacetime, as predicted by Einstein's general theory of relativity

openQuestions: Could the precise timing patterns of pulsars inspire new approaches to musical rhythm and temporal structures?
How might the frequency characteristics of pulsar signals relate to harmonic principles in music?
Could gravitational effects on signal timing provide insights into how massive objects might affect acoustic wave propagation?
What can the extreme regularity of millisecond pulsars teach us about precision in musical timing and tempo?

selected.extractionSummary: Robert Grant proposes a unified mathematical model connecting geometry and music through regular polygons inscribed in a unit circle. He advocates for Pythagorean tuning with A=432 Hz instead of the modern A=440 Hz standard, claiming this creates perfect geometric relationships where musical intervals correspond to specific polygon angles. The paper suggests these geometric-musical connections reveal fundamental relationships in nature, including a claimed connection between the F# frequency and the speed of light.

claims.text: Pythagorean tuning originally set the note A to 432 Hz, while modern tuning uses 440 Hz

citations.label: tuning_history
citations.quote: Although the modern tuning standard for the note A is 440hz, "true" Pythagorean tuning originally set the note A to 432hz

claims.text: Musical intervals can be mapped to regular polygons inscribed in a unit circle, with each note corresponding to specific angles

citations.label: geometric_mapping
citations.quote: Each note in the scale has 2 corresponding degree references within one unit circle (circumference = 360), as the unit circle encompasses 2 octaves

citations.label: triangle_example
citations.quote: For example, a B5 note following an A5 is 1.0833 x 432hz = 468hz, which lands at 300° (0.8333 of 360°) on a circle... Therefore, the B5 (468hz) creates an equilateral triangle

claims.text: The frequency of F# (720 Hz) corresponds to an angle that relates to the speed of light

citations.label: light_speed_connection
citations.quote: The seminal note of the Flower of Life (F#: 720hz) lands perfectly on the circle at 186.32 degrees, referencing light speed (186.28 x 10^3 miles per second) +/- .00001

claims.text: Half steps in music correspond to 30° angles on the unit circle

citations.label: half_step_angle
citations.quote: For example, the half step gap from A5 (432hz) to A#5 (450hz) would be 30° on the unit circle

details.description: Original chromatic tuning scale based on ratios discovered by Pythagoras

openQuestions: What is the historical evidence for Pythagorean tuning using A=432 Hz specifically?

selected.extractionSummary: This historical overview demonstrates that equal temperament is a modern 20th-century phenomenon, while earlier European music (1500-1900) used various unequal temperaments like meantone and well temperament. Each tuning system created different sonic qualities for different keys, with meantone favoring sweet major thirds in certain keys while making others unusable, and well temperaments allowing all keys but with distinct character differences. The author argues that playing historical music in modern equal temperament obscures the original compositional intentions and tonal colors that composers relied upon.

claims.text: Equal temperament was not widely used until the 20th century, with exact tuning methods only developed in 1917

citations.quote: Equal temperament - the bland, equal spacing of the 12 pitches of the octave - is pretty much a 20th-century phenomenon. It was known about in Europe as early as the early 17th century, and in China much earlier. But it wasn't used, because the consensus was that it sounded awful: out of tune and characterless.
Not until 1917 was a method devised for tuning exact equal temperament on the piano.

claims.text: Meantone tuning was Europe's most successful tuning system, lasting approximately 400 years from late 15th to early 18th century

citations.quote: Meantone tuning appeared sometime around the late 15th century, and was used widely through the early 18th century. In fact, it survived in pockets of resistance, especially in the tuning of English organs, all the way through the 19th century. No other tuning has survived in the west for 400 years.

claims.text: Notes closer together in frequency create faster and more disturbing beats than notes farther apart when out of tune

citations.quote: the notes in a slightly out-of-tune third, being closer together than those in a fifth, create faster and more disturbing beats than those in a slightly out-of-tune fifth. (I can confirm this from experience with my own Steinway grand, which I keep tuned to an 18th-century tuning.)

claims.text: Bach did not use equal temperament for The Well-Tempered Clavier, but rather well temperament that allowed playing in all keys while maintaining key-specific character

citations.quote: Bach did not use equal temperament. In fact, in his day there was no way to tune strings to equal temperament, because there were no devices to measure frequency.
Bach wrote The Well-Tempered Clavier in all 24 major and minor keys in order to capitalize on those differences, not because the differences didn't exist.

claims.text: Students can distinguish between appropriate and inappropriate keys for Bach preludes when played in historical temperament

citations.quote: I've done experiments with students at Bard and Bucknell, playing preludes from the W.T.C. in different keys on a sampled piano tuned to Werckmeister III... The students could often pick which was the appropriate key for each prelude

claims.text: Tuning has a pervasive influence on compositional tendencies and every piece of pitched music expresses a tuning system

citations.quote: Because it determines what sounds good, tuning has a pervasive influence on compositional tendencies. Every piece of pitched music is the expression of a tuning.

claims.text: 1/4-comma meantone is closely approximated by 31 equal steps to the octave

citations.quote: 1/4-comma meantone is very closely approximated (as was known in the 16th century) by a scale of 31 equal steps to the octave. Ten steps of such a scale equal 387.1 cents, which is a very good major third indeed.

openQuestions: How does playing historical music in original temperaments affect modern listener perception and appreciation?

selected.extractionSummary: Meantone temperaments are musical tuning systems that use slightly flattened fifths to produce purer major and minor thirds compared to Pythagorean tuning. Quarter-comma meantone was the dominant keyboard tuning from the early 16th to early 18th centuries, producing perfect 5:4 major thirds by tempering fifths by 1/4 of a syntonic comma. These systems create wolf intervals when confined to 12-note keyboards, but can be approximated by various equal temperament divisions like 31-TET for quarter-comma meantone.

claims.text: Perfect fifths in just intonation have a frequency ratio of 3:2

citations.quote: rather than using perfect fifths, consisting of frequency ratios of value 3:2

claims.text: Quarter-comma meantone produces just major thirds with a 5:4 ratio

citations.quote: Four ascending fifths (as C G D A E) tempered by 1/4 comma (and then lowered by two octaves) produce a just major third (C E) (with ratio 5: 4)

claims.text: In quarter-comma meantone, the whole tone is the geometric mean of the major tone (9:8) and minor tone (10:9)

citations.quote: as a frequency ratio, it is the geometric mean of the major tone and the minor tone: √(10/9 × 9/8) = √(5/4) = 1.1180340

claims.text: 12-tone equal temperament narrows perfect fifths by about 2 cents or 1/12 of a Pythagorean comma

citations.quote: it narrows the perfect fifths by about 2 cents or 1/12 of a Pythagorean comma to give a frequency ratio of 2^(7/12):1

claims.text: Meantone temperament was commonly used from early 16th century till early 18th century

citations.quote: It was commonly used from the early 16th century till the early 18th, after which twelve-tone equal temperament eventually came into general use

claims.text: 31-TET closely approximates quarter-comma meantone temperament

citations.quote: Quarter-comma meantone can be well approximated by a division of the octave into 31 equal steps

claims.text: Quarter-comma meantone creates a residual gap of 125/128 ratio or -41.06 cents between F# and Gb

citations.quote: there is a residual gap in quarter-comma meantone tuning between the last of the upper sequence of six fifths and the last of the lower sequence; e.g. between F♯ and G♭ if the starting point is chosen as C, which, adjusted for the octave, are in the ratio of 125/128 or −41.06 cents

claims.text: Third-comma meantone produces just minor thirds with a 6:5 ratio

citations.quote: three descending fifths (such as A D G C) produce a just minor third (A C) of ratio 6/5

selected.sourceTitle: Computational Extraction of Intonation and Tuning Systems
selected.extractionSummary: This paper presents a computational methodology for analyzing microtonal intonation in oral music traditions, using pitch histograms, Dynamic Time Warping, and optimization techniques. The authors applied their approach to 145 pieces of Iranian Classical Vocal Music to extract tuning systems directly from vocal performances. The methodology reveals four distinct types of pitch histogram peaks and uses optimization to align intervals across multiple recordings, capturing both performance flexibility and underlying systematic tendencies.

claims.text: Human voice provides a more authentic reference for Iranian musical intervals than musical instruments because instruments may introduce structural tuning constraints while the voice remains unbounded

citations.quote: In the foreword to Marufi's radif, Barkeshli emphasizes that the human voice provides a more authentic reference for Iranian musical intervals than musical instruments. Unlike instruments, which may introduce structural tuning constraints, the human voice remains unbounded, allowing for greater microtonal flexibility

claims.text: pYIN algorithm achieves 91% Raw Pitch Accuracy for monophonic vocal pitch recognition, outperforming CREPE at 90.5%

citations.quote: Gómez et al. evaluated two leading algorithms, CREPE and pYIN, for monophonic vocal pitch recognition. Their evaluation on the iKala dataset reported 91% Raw Pitch Accuracy for pYIN and 90.5% for CREPE

claims.text: Koron is a microtonal modification in Iranian Classical Music that lowers pitch by approximately a quarter-tone, though exact tuning varies by performance context

citations.quote: the p-shaped sign on the note E represents koron, a microtonal modification in Iranian Classical Music that lowers the pitch by approximately a quarter-tone, though its exact tuning varies depending on performance context

claims.text: In Iranian classical music, intervals labeled as 'neutral second' can vary from approximately 120 to 180 cents depending on context and transcriber's framework

citations.quote: what is labeled as a 'neutral second' in some cases may span anywhere from approximately 120 to 180 cents. In particular, we compared the intervals derived from audio performances with those found in musicological transcriptions of the same pieces. We observed notable inconsistencies, especially in the treatment of neutral intervals

claims.text: Four distinct types of pitch histogram peaks can be identified in microtonal vocal music: well-defined Gaussian peaks, hidden secondary peaks, double-peaked mountains, and flattened/curved peaks

citations.quote: Our analysis reveals several distinct types of peak structures, each with different implications for pitch estimation

details.description: MIDI pitch numbers doubled to accommodate sori (half-sharp) and koron (half-flat) intervals
Microtonal modifications approximately 50 cents from standard pitches
